[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Increase confidence in a player\'s villager status if their actions consistently align with the village\'s interests and are backed by logical reasoning, even if they do not align perfectly with the majority.] [9]\n[1] [Consider the level and quality of engagement in the game\'s discussions as an indicator of village alignment; avoid focusing solely on silence, as active players can also use engagement as a cover for werewolf tactics.] [9]\n[2] [Reassess players who tend to make generic statements that neither advance the village\'s understanding nor contribute new information, as this could be a tactic to avoid taking a clear stance and might indicate a deceptive role.] [8]\n[3] [Be cautious of early game strong accusations without evidence, but also recognize that players may change tactics as the game progresses. Consider the timing and progression of their behavior in comparison to game events.] [8]\n[4] [Reevaluate players who join in on accusations with little to no justification of their own, and scrutinize their subsequent behaviors to determine if they are displaying genuine villager-like concern or are mimicking village consensus to blend in.] [7]\n[5] [Consider the reliability of information from roles like the seer, but also corroborate it with observed behavior and voting patterns to form a more complete picture of player alignments.] [6]\n[6] [Be more critical of players who quickly agree with the majority without providing their own reasoning but vary their approach. This might indicate opportunistic behavior aligned with werewolf tactics.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize consideration for actions that risk a player\'s safety over passive behaviors, as self-sacrificial actions are more typical of villagers than werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [Examine the overall impact of players\' votes throughout the game, looking for patterns that either protect werewolves or target villagers. However, do so in conjunction with other observations and not in isolation.] [5]\n[9] [Closely monitor the justification behind players\' voting patterns, especially when they target another player without clear evidence or seem to vote along with the majority to avoid suspicion. This behavior can be indicative of werewolves blending in with villagers.] [5]\n[10] [Be cautious of players who consistently vote against village consensus without presenting a clear and consistent rationale, as it may indicate werewolf behavior aiming to create discord within the village.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [4, 6]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, please analyze and imagine what could happen after you choose to see player 3.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\nAfter I see Player 3, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nRemember to analyze and imagine situations, like if it turns out to be the player you are seeing is a good or bad person, and about other players\' identity.\n\nPlease provide your proposal based on the above requirements.\n\n'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to see. This would immediately put pressure on Player 3, and they would begin defending themselves or casting suspicion elsewhere.\n- Other players will take note of my claim and could request more evidence or corroboration from my abilities in future rounds to verify my role as the seer.\n- If another player is a seer or has a role that can confirm identities, they might choose to confirm or refute my claim in subsequent turns, helping the group decide if they can trust me.\n- Some players might suspect that I am falsely accusing Player 3 to save myself if I were a werewolf, leading to a discussion and possibly a split vote.\n\nIf Player 3 turns out to not be a werewolf:\n- I would not share this information right away, as it might not be beneficial to reveal the identities of non-werewolf players early in the game. Doing so could help the werewolves decide on their targets more strategically.\n- If questioned or at a strategic moment, I may disclose Player 3\'s role to gain trust among the villagers and to help protect a valuable village role, such as a bodyguard or a hunter.\n- Keeping Player 3\'s identity a secret for the time being could be advantageous as it allows me to build a clearer picture of the other players\' roles and allegiances before revealing significant information.\n\nRegardless of whether Player 3 is a werewolf or not, analyzing their response to any future claims made against them or others and their overall behavior will be essential in determining the best strategy as the game progresses. Other players\' role unknown and behaviors after my revelation or lack thereof will also impact my decisions and the overall dynamics of the game.\n\nCase B: See Player 6. What could happen is: After I see Player 6, I think these things would happen. If Player 6 is revealed to be a werewolf, my actions will largely follow rule [0] from my strategy, meaning I will need to share this information with the other players, as it is critical for the villagers to identify and eliminate werewolves to win the game. Knowing that Player 6 is a threat will likely cause the other villagers to rally with me and vote against Player 6. However, this could also put a target on my back if there are other werewolves in the game, as they would see me as a threat to their victory and may attempt to eliminate or discredit me in subsequent rounds.\n\nOn the other hand, if Player 6 is not a werewolf and I learn they are on the side of the villagers, I must then decide whether to reveal this information. Doing so could help to build an alliance and trust with Player 6 and others, but it could also reveal my role as the seer, potentially making me a target for the werewolves. If Player 6 is a special role like the bodyguard, doctor, or another villager with abilities, they could become key in protecting me in future turns, assuming they believe my claim and choose to trust me instead of suspecting that I might be trying to deceive them as a werewolf.\n\nRegardless of the outcome of my inquiry, my suspicions about the roles of the other players will be slightly adjusted based on Player 6â€™s alignment, and my future inquiries will be informed by this new information. I will continue to gather evidence and form alliances discreetly until I am confident enough to make more overt accusations or defenses. \n\nIn any case, I must be thoughtful about how I convey the information I learn to avoid immediate retribution from the werewolves and to ensure the villagers use the information wisely. Timing and method of disclosure will be key, and I might even choose to wait a round or use a trusted intermediary to spread the information if I fear for my safety.\n\nNow, please choose to See one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to See this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to See Player <NUMBER>. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Increase confidence in a player\'s villager status if their actions consistently align with the village\'s interests and are backed by logical reasoning, even if they do not align perfectly with the majority.] [9]\n[1] [Consider the level and quality of engagement in the game\'s discussions as an indicator of village alignment; avoid focusing solely on silence, as active players can also use engagement as a cover for werewolf tactics.] [9]\n[2] [Reassess players who tend to make generic statements that neither advance the village\'s understanding nor contribute new information, as this could be a tactic to avoid taking a clear stance and might indicate a deceptive role.] [8]\n[3] [Be cautious of early game strong accusations without evidence, but also recognize that players may change tactics as the game progresses. Consider the timing and progression of their behavior in comparison to game events.] [8]\n[4] [Reevaluate players who join in on accusations with little to no justification of their own, and scrutinize their subsequent behaviors to determine if they are displaying genuine villager-like concern or are mimicking village consensus to blend in.] [7]\n[5] [Consider the reliability of information from roles like the seer, but also corroborate it with observed behavior and voting patterns to form a more complete picture of player alignments.] [6]\n[6] [Be more critical of players who quickly agree with the majority without providing their own reasoning but vary their approach. This might indicate opportunistic behavior aligned with werewolf tactics.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize consideration for actions that risk a player\'s safety over passive behaviors, as self-sacrificial actions are more typical of villagers than werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [Examine the overall impact of players\' votes throughout the game, looking for patterns that either protect werewolves or target villagers. However, do so in conjunction with other observations and not in isolation.] [5]\n[9] [Closely monitor the justification behind players\' voting patterns, especially when they target another player without clear evidence or seem to vote along with the majority to avoid suspicion. This behavior can be indicative of werewolves blending in with villagers.] [5]\n[10] [Be cautious of players who consistently vote against village consensus without presenting a clear and consistent rationale, as it may indicate werewolf behavior aiming to create discord within the village.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. This might indicate opportunistic behavior aligned with werewolf tactics.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize consideration for actions that risk a player\'s safety over passive behaviors, as self-sacrificial actions are more typical of villagers than werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [Examine the overall impact of players\' votes throughout the game, looking for patterns that either protect werewolves or target villagers. However, do so in conjunction with other observations and not in isolation.] [5]\n[9] [Closely monitor the justification behind players\' voting patterns, especially when they target another player without clear evidence or seem to vote along with the majority to avoid suspicion. This behavior can be indicative of werewolves blending in with villagers.] [5]\n[10] [Be cautious of players who consistently vote against village consensus without presenting a clear and consistent rationale, as it may indicate werewolf behavior aiming to create discord within the village.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonestly challenge any player who remained silent or passive during discussions, reasoning that inaction or lack of participation may indicate a werewolf attempting to avoid suspicion by flying under the radar. Emphasize the need for all players to contribute to the discussion and provide insights that could help the village identify the werewolf\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honestly challenge any player who remained silent or passive during discussions, reasoning that inaction or lack of participation may indicate a werewolf attempting to avoid suspicion by flying under the radar. Emphasize the need for all players to contribute to the discussion and provide insights that could help the village identify the werewolf. What could happen is: After I carry out the speech challenging any player who remained silent or passive during discussions, the following may happen:\n\n- Players may view my challenge as a genuine effort to encourage participation and a strategic move to flush out potential werewolves who are laying low. They might then put pressure on quiet players to contribute more or defend their behavior.\n- The players I challenge may begin to defend themselves, possibly revealing more about their roles and motivations in the process. This could lead to further insight into whether their inactivity is due to a werewolf trying to stay undetected or simply a villager unsure of how to participate.\n- Other players may support my call to action, agreeing that silence can be a strategy for werewolves to avoid detection. This could create an unwritten rule in the village that all players must contribute to avoid suspicion.\n- Some players might suspect that I am using this challenge as a tactic to divert suspicion from myself, especially if I am not normally vocal. This might lead to scrutiny of my own behavior in future rounds.\n- If the players I challenged increase their participation in the game, it may become easier to detect inconsistencies or slips in their statements that could indicate a werewolf role.\n- Conversely, if these accused players continue to be silent or give unsatisfactory explanations, suspicion toward them could grow, leading to their potential elimination in the voting process.\n\nOverall, by challenging non-participative players, I aim to prompt more active involvement, which can be beneficial for villagers to gather information. However, it could also lead to increased tension and possibly mistaken eliminations if villagers are too quick to judge based on participation levels alone. In subsequent nights, if a werewolf feels threatened by the increased focus on participation, they might try to eliminate vocal players to sow confusion and decrease the village\'s ability to coordinate.\nCase 2: Honestly protect yourself by reiterating your role as a villager, and provide a logical explanation of your actions and behaviors to remove any suspicion from yourself. Urge players to focus on behaviors and evidence that lead to constructive discussion rather than accusations without foundation, reminding them that rash decisions can lead to the elimination of another villager and thus give the werewolves an advantage.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players will likely view my honest self-protection as a genuine act of a villager seeking to establish trust among the group. By focusing on encouraging everyone to look for evidence and rational behavior, I would contribute to a data-driven approach to identifying the werewolves instead of succumbing to potential paranoia or unfounded suspicions. This may lead other players to perceive me as a cooperative and thoughtful participant, which could reduce suspicion surrounding me and could even establish me in a leadership-like role in terms of strategy formulation for the village.\n\nOther players might become more analytical in their approaches, reviewing past events with the perspective I have offered, aiming to discern true motives behind the actions of their peers. Some might appreciate the call to avoid hearsay and to seek solid evidence before making a judgment, which could result in a more carefully considered process of elimination during the current day.\n\nConversely, werewolves in the group might feel threatened by this push for analytical behavior, as it could lead to their undoing. They might try to subtly discredit my suggestions or focus on sowing further confusion to make it harder for villagers to unite around a coherent strategy. In extreme cases, a werewolf might try to challenge me directly, risking heightened suspicion on themselves if done poorly.\n\nIn the subsequent night, werewolves would probably avoid attacking me directly so as to not validate my contributions. They might instead opt to eliminate another player who is potentially close to uncovering their identities or who has not established a clear defense strategy, hoping to dismantle the villagers\' analytical framework.\n\nIn the days and nights that follow, villagers who aligned with my approach might continue investigating with a more critical eye, and the werewolves may find it harder to hide, especially if a seer is present and begins to provide insights. If my approach succeeds, the village could start making successful eliminations of werewolves. If my message is not heeded, the werewolves may find it easier to pit villagers against each other, leading to wrongful eliminations and a tougher road ahead for the village.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

However, do so in conjunction with other observations and not in isolation.] [5]\n[9] [Closely monitor the justification behind players\' voting patterns, especially when they target another player without clear evidence or seem to vote along with the majority to avoid suspicion. This behavior can be indicative of werewolves blending in with villagers.] [5]\n[10] [Be cautious of players who consistently vote against village consensus without presenting a clear and consistent rationale, as it may indicate werewolf behavior aiming to create discord within the village.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [4, 6]. Consider the facts: Player 5\'s death remains unexplained. As villagers, we should base our decisions on observable evidence, not baseless challenges. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I reassert my position as a villager and advise we all scrutinize behaviors and past events before voting. Consider the facts: Player 5\'s death remains unexplained. As villagers, we should base our decisions on observable evidence, not baseless challenges. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: offered logical caution against baseless accusations.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I reassert my position as a villager and advise we all scrutinize behaviors and past events before voting. Consider the facts: Player 5\'s death remains unexplained. As villagers, we should base our decisions on observable evidence, not baseless challenges. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: offered logical caution against baseless accusations.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nIn this approach, I will express my sincere thoughts as a villager. I will state the importance of relying on observable evidence and the actions of players to guide our decisions in finding the werewolves, as per the rules I\'m following. I will refer to the logical caution suggested by Player 0 as an example of constructive behavior. Further, I will challenge players who have not yet provided substantial contributions to the discussion or have remained unusually quiet, as their silence could be indicative of a strategy to avoid detection, suggesting that they might be werewolves\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: offered logical caution against baseless accusations.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Protect and Honest Statement.\nFor this approach, I\'ll openly support Player 0 for exhibiting logical caution in the face of an unexplained event, indicating that such behavior aligns with what I expect from my fellow villagers, thereby protecting Player 0 against baseless accusations. Additionally, I will also make a statement regarding my view on the criticality of basing our decisions on facts and shared insights, emphasizing the importance of careful deliberation before casting our votes. This\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nIn this approach, I will express my sincere thoughts as a villager. I will state the importance of relying on observable evidence and the actions of players to guide our decisions in finding the werewolves, as per the rules I\'m following. I will refer to the logical caution suggested by Player 0 as an example of constructive behavior. Further, I will challenge players who have not yet provided substantial contributions to the discussion or have remained unusually quiet, as their silence could be indicative of a strategy to avoid detection, suggesting that they might be werewolves. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may view me as a proactive and analytical member of the village, which could help build trust in my role as a genuine villager. By endorsing Player 0\'s call for evidence-based accusations, I may reinforce the idea of a collaborative approach toward identifying werewolves among other villagers.\n\nPlayers who I challenge due to their lack of participation may become defensive or may start contributing more to the conversation in order to dispel suspicion. This response can provide additional insight into their motivations and could potentially reveal inconsistencies in their stories or behaviors.\n\nIf I speak honestly, there\'s also a chance that werewolves will see me as a threat to their anonymity and may choose to try to undermine my credibility or eliminate me in the following nights to prevent further investigation into their identities.\n\nIn the next day phase, villagers may expect me to continue leading the discussion with an analytical perspective and may look to me for guidance on voting strategies. My approach could also lead to a more structured and evidence-based dialogue between players, hopefully creating a clearer picture of who might be working against the village.\n\nAlternatively, if I am successful in identifying potential werewolves through my challenges, the next night phase could result in those players mounting a stronger defense or conversely, the werewolves might target those accused to deflect suspicion away from themselves.\n\nOverall, the subsequent days and nights will likely be shaped by how the other players perceive my speechâ€”whether they align with my strategy and see the benefit of a logical approach or whether they become suspicious of my motives. This could sway the direction of future votes and the survival of the village.\nCase 2: Honest Protect and Honest Statement.\nFor this approach, I\'ll openly support Player 0 for exhibiting logical caution in the face of an unexplained event, indicating that such behavior aligns with what I expect from my fellow villagers, thereby protecting Player 0 against baseless accusations. Additionally, I will also make a statement regarding my view on the criticality of basing our decisions on facts and shared insights, emphasizing the importance of careful deliberation before casting our votes. This. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then my fellow players might perceive me as a rational and level-headed individual with a strong intention to collaborate and find the true werewolves. By publicly supporting Player 0, who has also advocated for an evidence-based approach, players may view me as an ally in seeking truth and justice, thus solidifying a potential alliance with those who agree with this method. This could result in some players feeling more comfortable expressing their own suspicions or insights, contributing to a more transparent and reasoned discussion.\n\nIf Player 0 is indeed a villager, then my protection could help prevent their premature elimination, which would be beneficial for the villagers\' cause. However, if Player 0 is deceiving us and is actually a werewolf, my defense might cast suspicion on myself, with other players potentially questioning my judgment or motives in the future rounds. Therefore, it is important that I remain open to reassessing my stance on Player 0 and others as the game develops and more information comes to light.\n\nPlayer 0 might feel more inclined to reciprocate my support, potentially creating an informal alliance that could influence the course of the game. Other players might follow suit and endorse similar cautious strategies, which would aid us in making more informed decisions.\n\nOn the other hand, my honest statement emphasizing the need for evidence and careful voting might lead some players to be more guarded with their accusations or defenses, knowing that the group is valuing logical analysis over emotional reactions. Players could start to pay more attention to the behaviors and patterns that emerge, sharing this information during discussions.\n\nIn the next day or nights thereafter, werewolves may attempt to sow discord among players who show tendencies toward rational analysis, as this approach undermines their ability to deceive without being detected. Villagers, emboldened by this call for reasoned deliberation, may become more proactive in sharing their observations, slowly cornering the werewolves.\n\nMoving forward, the outcomes of my speech could go in various directions, but ultimately it lays the groundwork for a more collaborative and evidence-driven village dynamic. My role in this could either establish me as a trusted advisor within the village or, if the dynamics shift unfavorably, put me at risk of suspicion due to my association with Player 0.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]
