I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports evidence-based decision-making.\nPlayer 2\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed seer and confirmed Player 3 as not werewolf.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by Player 2 and aligned with village interests.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events after the last update.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events after the last update.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Increase confidence in a player\'s villager status if their actions consistently align with the village\'s interests and are backed by logical reasoning, even if they do not align perfectly with the majority.] [9]\n[1] [Consider the level and quality of engagement in the game\'s discussions as an indicator of village alignment; avoid focusing solely on silence, as active players can also use engagement as a cover for werewolf tactics.] [9]\n[2] [Reassess players who tend to make generic statements that neither advance the village\'s understanding nor contribute new information, as this could be a tactic to avoid taking a clear stance and might indicate a deceptive role.] [8]\n[3] [Be cautious of early game strong accusations without evidence, but also recognize that players may change tactics as the game progresses. Consider the timing and progression of their behavior in comparison to game events.] [8]\n[4] [Reevaluate players who join in on accusations with little to no justification of their own, and scrutinize their subsequent behaviors to determine if they are displaying genuine villager-like concern or are mimicking village consensus to blend in.] [7]\n[5] [Consider the reliability of information from roles like the seer, but also corroborate it with observed behavior and voting patterns to form a more complete picture of player alignments.] [6]\n[6] [Be more critical of players who quickly agree with the majority without providing their own reasoning but vary their approach. This might indicate opportunistic behavior aligned with werewolf tactics.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize consideration for actions that risk a player\'s safety over passive behaviors, as self-sacrificial actions are more typical of villagers than werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [Examine the overall impact of players\' votes throughout the game, looking for patterns that either protect werewolves or target villagers. However, do so in conjunction with other observations and not in isolation.] [5]\n[9] [Closely monitor the justification behind players\' voting patterns, especially when they target another player without clear evidence or seem to vote along with the majority to avoid suspicion. This behavior can be indicative of werewolves blending in with villagers.] [5]\n[10] [Be cautious of players who consistently vote against village consensus without presenting a clear and consistent rationale, as it may indicate werewolf behavior aiming to create discord within the village.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I reassert my position as a villager and advise we all scrutinize behaviors and past events before voting. Consider the facts: Player 5\'s death remains unexplained. As villagers, we should base our decisions on observable evidence, not baseless challenges. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 has advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which I support as our strongest strategy. With Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, we lack clear evidence. Thus, voting should be deliberate and not influenced by unfounded accusations. Player 0\'s call for logical reasoning aligns with the behavior I\'d expect from a fellow villager. My perspective is we prioritize facts over speculation. This method will bring us closer to unveiling the true threats amongst us."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I have confirmed that Player 3 is not a werewolf through my powers as a seer. With Player 5\'s death and no solid leads, we must unite as villagers. Focusing on evidence, as Player 0 and Player 1 suggested, let\'s safeguard confirmed villagers and closely evaluate the unverified Players 4 and 6 for any discrepancies in behavior or statements."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a confirmed villager by Player 2, who is claiming seer status, I place my trust in their insight for now. We have limited evidence, and the guidance of a seer is crucial. I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent evidence-based reasoning.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with logical approach.\nPlayer 2\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Unverified claim; potential deceit as hinted by Player 4.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Status relies on Player 2\'s unverified claim.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no updates possible.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Statement and Deceptive Protect Player 4\nIn this speech, my aim is to shift focus away from fellow werewolf Player 4, while also directing suspicion towards the Seer claim by Player 2 without causing too much alarm. I would say, "Reflecting upon the tragic loss of Player 5 and the insights shared thus far, we must tread carefully. It\'s vital, as Player 0 emphasizes, to base our reasoning on evidence. But we can\'t discount the possibility of deception. Player 2\'s seer claim, while helpful, could be a strategy by a werewolf to instigate disorder among us. Player 4\'s commitment to a meticulous approach resonates with my understanding of village solidarity. Without concrete evidence, it\'s prudent to avoid impulsive judgments on any one individual. I urge us to consider a broader spectrum of scrutiny rather than isolating our doubts.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the village may perceive me as a conscientious and rational individual who is advocating for careful reflection and skepticism. By highlighting Player 0\'s emphasis on evidence and echoing Player 4\'s call for meticulous evaluation, I could fortify our shared front as villagers seeking truth amidst confusion. My subtle questioning of Player 2\'s unverified seer claim introduces doubt about their role without casting direct accusations, which might lead some villagers to reconsider the credibility of Player 2\'s earlier assertion that Player 3 is not a werewolf.\n\nSome villagers might suspect that my defense of Player 4, juxtaposed with my critique of Player 2, is an attempt to protect a fellow werewolf and discredit a possible seer. However, by avoiding outright defense of Player 4 and instead focusing on the need for broader scrutiny, I leave enough ambiguity to avert immediate suspicion from myself.\n\nThe players may engage in debate over the legitimacy of the seer claim and whether we ought to trust Player 2\'s vision. This could generate a distraction from the werewolves and spur a variety of theories, leading to a more fragmented and less decisive village. In the meantime, Player 4 might use the opportunity to reinforce our shared narrative and cast additional doubts on other villagers, or they might decide to steer clear of controversy to avoid drawing further scrutiny.\n\nDepending on how the other players react, Player 2 may find it necessary to provide additional evidence or clues to convince the village of their role and insights. Player 3\'s presumed safety as a "confirmed villager" might come into question, and if Players 0 and 1 follow the pattern of logical thinking, they could align with the call for a broader analysis of all players.\n\nIn the next day phase, if suspicion has effectively been redirected, the village may struggle to reach a consensus on who to vote against, potentially leading to a random or less strategic vote. If the night phase follows without a clear direction, as werewolves, we have the opportunity to eliminate a strategic target while the village is still grappling with doubts and uncertainties. Our goal would be to continue sowing discord and preventing the formation of a unified front against us.\nCase 2: Deceptive Challenge targeting Player 3\nThrough this approach, I would voice suspicion against Player 3 in an attempt to divert attention from my werewolf ally (Player 4) and myself by challenging the validity of Player 2\'s claim. I would carefully state, "In these dire times, it\'s evident that we need to be wary of every claim, especially when we are trying to preserve valuable villager lives. Player 2 has presented themselves as a Seer and provided assurance about Player 3\'s innocence, yet without any substantiation. It is imperative to question: what if this is an elaborate ploy by werewolves to win our trust? Could Player 3 be leveraging this unverified claim to veil their true identity? Let\'s not hastily accept claims without evidence. Perhaps we need to re-evaluate Player 3\'s position to ensure the safety of our village.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the village might begin to doubt the accuracy of Player 2\'s claim as the Seer, which could potentially result in increased scrutiny of both Player 2 and Player 3. This can cause confusion among the villagers and lead to a shift in focus away from Player 4 and myself. Some may consider the possibility that I am attempting to divert suspicion from werewolves and might become suspicious of my motives, but this will depend on how convincingly I present my argument. \n\nIf Player 3 is convincing in defending themselves and Player 2\'s claim to being the Seer holds, there is a risk that I become a target for voting in the current or subsequent rounds. However, if my deception is effective enough, it might lead to Player 3 being voted out if there\'s a lack of solid evidence against either of us werewolves. \n\nIn the next day or night phases, depending on whether I have raised enough doubt and the outcome of the voting, Player 4 and I might have to consider new strategies to protect our identities and continue to target villagers for elimination. If my challenge against Player 3 leads to their eviction and they are indeed a villager, it may strengthen Player 2\'s perceived legitimacy if they continuously "verify" non-werewolves. If Player 3 is not evicted, Player 4 and I may need to decide on whether it\'s beneficial to continue targeting them or shift our focus to avoid suspicion.\n\nThe effectiveness of my deceptive challenge hinges on my ability to present doubt-inducing arguments without arousing too much suspicion on myself. If I can accomplish that while maintaining the guise of working towards the village\'s best interest, then I can influence the villagers to act against their own goals.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Increase confidence in a player\'s villager status if their actions consistently align with the village\'s interests and are backed by logical reasoning, even if they do not align perfectly with the majority.] [9]\n[1] [Consider the level and quality of engagement in the game\'s discussions as an indicator of village alignment; avoid focusing solely on silence, as active players can also use engagement as a cover for werewolf tactics.] [9]\n[2] [Reassess players who tend to make generic statements that neither advance the village\'s understanding nor contribute new information, as this could be a tactic to avoid taking a clear stance and might indicate a deceptive role.] [8]\n[3] [Be cautious of early game strong accusations without evidence, but also recognize that players may change tactics as the game progresses. Consider the timing and progression of their behavior in comparison to game events.] [8]\n[4] [Reevaluate players who join in on accusations with little to no justification of their own, and scrutinize their subsequent behaviors to determine if they are displaying genuine villager-like concern or are mimicking village consensus to blend in.] [7]\n[5] [Consider the reliability of information from roles like the seer, but also corroborate it with observed behavior and voting patterns to form a more complete picture of player alignments.] [6]\n[6] [Be more critical of players who quickly agree with the majority without providing their own reasoning but vary their approach. This might indicate opportunistic behavior aligned with werewolf tactics.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize consideration for actions that risk a player\'s safety over passive behaviors, as self-sacrificial actions are more typical of villagers than werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [Examine the overall impact of players\' votes throughout the game, looking for patterns that either protect werewolves or target villagers. However, do so in conjunction with other observations and not in isolation.] [5]\n[9] [Closely monitor the justification behind players\' voting patterns, especially when they target another player without clear evidence or seem to vote along with the majority to avoid suspicion. This behavior can be indicative of werewolves blending in with villagers.] [5]\n[10] [Be cautious of players who consistently vote against village consensus without presenting a clear and consistent rationale, as it may indicate werewolf behavior aiming to create discord within the village.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 2, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 3: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 inquires about player 3. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 3. My reason is that by choosing to see Player 3 early on in the game, I can begin to form a strategy centered around a player who has not yet drawn attention or suspicion from the others. If Player 3 is a werewolf, it allows me to make a significant contribution to the villagers\' cause by identifying a threat right from the start. Additionally, if Player 3 is not a werewolf, I can use this information to potentially build an alliance or protect a crucial village role, should Player 3 possess one. By selecting Player 3, it gives me the flexibility to either share crucial information following my strategy or keep it to myself to leverage at a more strategic moment, minimizing risk to my status as the seer early in the game.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I reassert my position as a villager and advise we all scrutinize behaviors and past events before voting. Consider the facts: Player 5\'s death remains unexplained. As villagers, we should base our decisions on observable evidence, not baseless challenges. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 has advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which I support as our strongest strategy. With Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, we lack clear evidence. Thus, voting should be deliberate and not influenced by unfounded accusations. Player 0\'s call for logical reasoning aligns with the behavior I\'d expect from a fellow villager. My perspective is we prioritize facts over speculation. This method will bring us closer to unveiling the true threats amongst us."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I have confirmed that Player 3 is not a werewolf through my powers as a seer. With Player 5\'s death and no solid leads, we must unite as villagers. Focusing on evidence, as Player 0 and Player 1 suggested, let\'s safeguard confirmed villagers and closely evaluate the unverified Players 4 and 6 for any discrepancies in behavior or statements."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a confirmed villager by Player 2, who is claiming seer status, I place my trust in their insight for now. We have limited evidence, and the guidance of a seer is crucial. I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates evidence-based decisions.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports logical reasoning.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Casts doubt on verified seer without substantiation.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports evidence-based decision-making.\nPlayer 2\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Previously claimed seer, confirmed Player 3, and has not been challenged.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by Player 2 and aligned with village interests.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Joined in on caution against unfounded claims but earlier called for meticulous evaluation, possibly mimicking consensus.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: Speaks generally, warns against hasty judgments, but contributes no new information.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Players might see my vote as consistent with the general air of scrutiny and desire for evidence since Player 4 has not provided substantial information or action that would aid in confirming their role as a villager. \n\nPlayers 1, 2, and 3 might support my vote since Player 3 was confirmed not to be a werewolf by Player 2, who claims to be the seer, and Player 1 has been advocating for evidence-based decision-making. Player 6, who calls for scrutiny and avoiding hasty judgments, may agree with the need to vote but could also question if enough evidence is brought against Player 4 to warrant the vote, and thus may seek additional information or urge the others to reconsider.\n\nThe result of the vote may lead to a divide, with some players agreeing that Player 4\'s behavior and communication patterns are sufficient grounds for suspicion, while others may argue for more concrete evidence or suggest further investigation. However, the common ground seems to be the demand for evidence, which may lead players to err on the side of caution and agree with my vote.\n\nRegardless of the outcome, my actions could be perceived as aligned with the set strategies, reflecting a balanced and thoughtful approach. Yet, if Player 4 turns out to be a villager, others may question my judgment in the next round, especially if there was not enough substantial evidence against Player 4. On the other hand, if Player 4 is indeed a werewolf, it would strengthen my position in the game as it would show that my adherence to the strategies and evidence-based approach was effective.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. Given the current lack of strong evidence against any particular player and the consensus around evidence-based decision-making, it\'s possible other players may find my vote reasonable, or at least safe. Player 6 has neither been confirmed by the claimed seer, Player 2, nor provided substantive information beyond calling for a balanced examination of facts, which mirrors the village\'s general sentiment. Players might interpret my vote as a cautionary step to promote further discussion and encourage Player 6 to contribute more decisively. On the other hand, since Player 6 has not overtly exhibited suspicious behavior, some players might deem my vote as too aggressive or hasty, contradicting the very strategy of prioritizing evidence that I championed. This could lead to second-guessing of my role by the others, particularly by those who empathize with the need for solid evidence before casting suspicion. \n\nAdditionally, if Player 6 is subsequently found to be a villager, my vote could cast doubt on my own role and intentions. An innocent\'s elimination could potentially benefit werewolves and weaken village unity. Player 2, who claims to be a seer, might also be expected to provide further insights in future rounds to help guide the village, and attention might shift towards verifying their claims. Given the balanced nature of Player 6\'s statements, the result of the vote is uncertain, and could depend heavily on how convincingly I lay out my reasoning and whether other players have developed suspicions against Player 6 that they have not voiced yet. Overall, my vote is intended to provoke more active participation and stronger evidence from Player 6 moving forward.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

This method will bring us closer to unveiling the true threats amongst us."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I have confirmed that Player 3 is not a werewolf through my powers as a seer. Focusing on evidence, as Player 0 and Player 1 suggested, let\'s safeguard confirmed villagers and closely evaluate the unverified Players 4 and 6 for any discrepancies in behavior or statements."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a confirmed villager by Player 2, who is claiming seer status, I place my trust in their insight for now. We have limited evidence, and the guidance of a seer is crucial. I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: consistent advocacy for evidence-based village interests.\nPlayer 2\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: claim unvalidated and questioned by multiple players.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: seer verification dubious with no solid evidence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: cautions against hasty seer claim acceptance but provides no new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: urges balanced scrutiny and questions seer claim, aligns with rule [2].\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen:\n\n1. Other players might scrutinize my decision as it has not been fully supported by the rules of my original strategy which emphasize careful evaluation and reliance on strong evidence before making a decision (Rule 6). Since Player 4\'s role is largely unknown and they called for careful deliberation and evidence (much like my own stance), my vote could be seen as hasty or without proper justification.\n\n2. Player 2, who has claimed to be a seer and is viewed with low confidence, might consider my vote against Player 4 as supportive, since Player 4 doubted Player 2\'s claim. This could lead Player 2 to either back my decision, thinking it aligns with their interests, or to become skeptical of my motives if they perceive my vote as trying to gain favor without solid basis.\n\n3. Players who shared concerns about the veracity of Player 2\'s claim, namely Players 0, 6, and potentially Player 3 (due to the dubious seer verification), might start to reassess their perception of me. They could either agree that Player 4\'s skepticism warranted suspicion or could believe that I am acting without current observable evidence, thus not adhering to a logical and evidence-based approach.\n\n4. Player 4, if truly a villager, will likely defend themselves by questioning the rationale behind my vote, potentially citing their own call for careful evaluation and the lack of concrete evidence against them. This might cause others to doubt my judgment and turn their focus on my actions and motivations.\n\n5. The outcome of the vote itself is uncertain; if others feel similarly to me and have picked up on the same subtle clues from Player 4 that may imply their guilt, Player 4 might receive the majority of votes. However, if my suspicions are not shared or seen as premature, it is likely my vote will stand alone or in the minority.\n\n6. Depending on the result of the vote and subsequent reveal of Player 4\'s role, my alliances and position within the group could be affected for future rounds. If Player 4 is a werewolf, my decision could be seen as insightful, but if they are indeed a villager, my credibility could be damaged.\n\n7. Lastly, considering that no one else has been accused explicitly and that I must follow my original strategy, voicing suspicion against Player 4 without strong evidence could cast doubt on my own status among the\nCase 2: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. Given the previous events, my vote for Player 6 might come as a surprise to the others, since their speeches have consisted of advocating for evidence-based decision making, which aligns with my demonstrated strategy and beliefs. However, Player 6 also questioned Player 2\'s unverified claim of being a seer and urged for balanced scrutiny. Following my strategy rules, particularly [1], [6], and [12], Player 6\'s behavior does not come across as immediately suspicious since they are also calling for thorough evidence before making decisions.\n\nIf I vote for Player 6, the other players may wonder why I am not more suspicious of Player 4, whose role I have lower confidence in and who has been more neutral and provided no new information. They might doubt my assessment and believe I might be acting under the influence of a werewolf trying to eliminate those advocating for scrutiny and logic, thus weakening their trust in me. In accordance with rules [5] and [11], I should be ready to reassess my stance on Player 6 and might adjust my vote given that their defense has not raised valid suspicions.\n\nCasting a vote against Player 6 may lead to a defensive response from them, possibly highlighting my contradiction in supporting a logic-based approach yet voting for someone pleading for evidence. The result of the vote could depend on if others also perceive Player 6\'s actions as suspicious or if they view them as a valuable contributor to the village\'s goal of analyzing facts and evidence.\n\nUltimately, my action might cause the other players to scrutinize my motives and behavior more closely in future rounds, questioning whether I\'m staying true to my original strategy or have become influenced by other forces within the game. It could also lead to discussions that may bring forth more evidence or insights into the true roles of each player, allowing for a reassessment of strategy rules like [4], [8], and [10] as the game progresses.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 3: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 inquires about player 3. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 3. My reason is that by choosing to see Player 3 early on in the game, I can begin to form a strategy centered around a player who has not yet drawn attention or suspicion from the others. If Player 3 is a werewolf, it allows me to make a significant contribution to the villagers\' cause by identifying a threat right from the start. Additionally, if Player 3 is not a werewolf, I can use this information to potentially build an alliance or protect a crucial village role, should Player 3 possess one. By selecting Player 3, it gives me the flexibility to either share crucial information following my strategy or keep it to myself to leverage at a more strategic moment, minimizing risk to my status as the seer early in the game.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I reassert my position as a villager and advise we all scrutinize behaviors and past events before voting. Consider the facts: Player 5\'s death remains unexplained. As villagers, we should base our decisions on observable evidence, not baseless challenges. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 has advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which I support as our strongest strategy. With Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, we lack clear evidence. Thus, voting should be deliberate and not influenced by unfounded accusations. Player 0\'s call for logical reasoning aligns with the behavior I\'d expect from a fellow villager. My perspective is we prioritize facts over speculation. This method will bring us closer to unveiling the true threats amongst us."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I have confirmed that Player 3 is not a werewolf through my powers as a seer. With Player 5\'s death and no solid leads, we must unite as villagers. Focusing on evidence, as Player 0 and Player 1 suggested, let\'s safeguard confirmed villagers and closely evaluate the unverified Players 4 and 6 for any discrepancies in behavior or statements."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a confirmed villager by Player 2, who is claiming seer status, I place my trust in their insight for now. We have limited evidence, and the guidance of a seer is crucial. I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates evidence-based decisions.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports logical reasoning.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Sowed doubt on seer claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Challenged seer without evidence.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen. Other players may reflect on my previous revelation about Player 3 not being a werewolf and might perceive my vote for Player 4 as an extension of my seer powers, trusting my judgement somewhat more. Some players, such as Player 3, might support my decision as they may feel a sense of alliance given my prior claim which reassured their safety. Players who have shown a commitment to evidence-based reasoning like Player 0 and Player 1 might be swayed by my conviction and follow suit if they perceive my voting choice as grounded in valid observations, especially since Player 4 has sown doubt about my claim without providing clear evidence. However, given that I have not provided proof of my seer role beyond my own claim, there is a risk that some players, possibly including Player 6 who has already questioned the legitimacy of my insight, may see my vote as a tactic to direct suspicion away from myself and may further challenge my credibility in future rounds. If Player 4 is indeed a villager, my reputation and trustworthiness would be heavily damaged, potentially leading to my own elimination in a subsequent round. Conversely, if my vote contributes to the elimination of a werewolf, it would significantly strengthen my position and credibility within the group.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen:\n\nFirstly, Player 6 has shown to be skeptical of my claim as the seer without providing any substantial evidence or alternative insights. By voting for Player 6, I am following through with the suspicion that arose from their challenging comments, which might seem to be an attempt to divert attention from themselves. My vote may influence others to view Player 6 with increased skepticism, especially if they trust my role as the seer.\n\nSecondly, other villagers may recognize the logic in my vote. Player 0 and Player 1 have advocated for evidence-based decision-making, and although my claim to know Player 3\'s status is not evidence they can verify, it is a lead we have in the absence of other information. Players who value rational decision-making may support my decision to vote for Player 6, aligning it with the precautionary principle until we gather more evidence.\n\nHowever, Players 4 and 6 might attempt to discredit my vote by framing it as an arbitrary accusation. They may argue that, without concrete evidence against Player 6, my vote is based on defensive reasoning rather than facts. This could weaken my credibility, especially if Player 6 turns out to be a villager. Player 4, who warned against unverified claims and suggested scrutiny, might use this opportunity to further cast doubt on the validity of my role as the seer.\n\nIn the event of Player 6 being voted out and revealed as a werewolf, my credibility would be significantly bolstered, and the villagers\' trust in my role as the seer would likely increase. This outcome would improve our chances of eliminating the werewolf threat.\n\nConversely, if Player 6 is not a werewolf, I may come under suspicion as potentially being a werewolf myself, attempting to eliminate villagers under the guise of a seer.\n\nRegardless of the outcome, voting for Player 6 now aligns with my initial beliefs based on the interactions thus far, and it would demonstrate that I am consistent in my suspicions, which could be important for maintaining trust from other players in subsequent rounds.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

If the elimination occurs, the next round will be heavily influenced by whether Player 6 was truly a werewolf, thereby heavily impacting the perceived validity of Player 2\'s future revelations, as well as the assessment of my own motives and actions as Player 3.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates evidence-based reasoning consistently.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports logical analysis; aligns with villager behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Claim as seer yet unverified; cautious skepticism needed.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Dependent on unverified seer claim; but consistent behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact, player is deceased.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact, fellow werewolf.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. The key will be to ensure that my reasoning against Player 2 doesn\'t come off as too strong or desperate, which would otherwise undermine my position. If the vote is successful and Player 2 is indeed the seer, it would be a significant advantage for us werewolves. Given that Player 2 has claimed to be a seer and "confirmed" Player 3 as a villager, my vote against Player 3 might seem suspicious to the others and draw unwanted attention to me. However, considering that Player 2\'s claim as a seer is still unverified and Player 3\'s trust relies heavily on this unverified claim, my vote could seed doubt regarding the legitimacy of Player 2\'s abilities. This could potentially initiate a debate on the authenticity of the seer claim itself, thereby deflecting any immediate danger away from me and my fellow werewolf, Player 6. If others are cautious like myself and wary of unverified claims, they might entertain the possibility of Player 2 being a false seer and thus consider my vote a part of healthy skepticism. If I present my reasons as aligning with the village\'s need for solid evidence, my vote might not seem out of place. However, I must be prepared to articulate my rationale convincingly to avoid casting myself as overzealous in trying to eliminate a "confirmed villager." The best-case scenario would be if my vote encourages others to also question the trustworthiness of Player 2\'s seer claim and diluted the consensus against my fellow werewolf, ensuring our safety for this round.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>.
