It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent reasoning and evidence-based approach.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported logical, evidence-based decision-making.\nPlayer 2\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Early claim remains unverified.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Innocence based on unverified seer claim.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Partner werewolf; consistent with previous belief.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no updates possible.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. This could lead to further confusion among the villagers during the next round of discussions. However, by aligning with the consensus of requiring evidence and acknowledging the lack of verification on Player 2\'s claim, I can justify my vote as being in line with the village\'s logic (Rule 4, Rule 5).\n\nMy argument in defense could emphasize the need to scrutinize all claims, pointing out the risks of taking Player 2\'s declaration at face value without concrete evidence, echoing the communal call for evidence-based decision-making. Nevertheless, I have to be careful not to appear too aggressive in my defiance to avoid drawing direct suspicion to myself (Rule 9, Rule 10).\nCase 2: Vote for Player 1. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 1, I think these things would happen. Since Players 0 and 1 have been establishing themselves as evidence-focused villagers, my vote against Player 1 may seem counterintuitive and might draw suspicion towards me. It could be perceived as an attempt to sow discord amongst villagers since Player 1 has not been the focal point of any major suspicion. Moreover, my previous statement during the discussion underscored the necessity of evidence, and a vote against Player 1 could seem inconsistent with that sentiment, as there is no concrete evidence suggesting Player 1 is a werewolf. Players may begin to question my motives, believing that Iâ€™m trying to divert attention away from myself and Player 4, who have been noted as unverified by Player 2. Other villagers may scrutinize my vote and behavior in future rounds more closely. However, it could also create a dynamic where other players begin to doubt the credibility of Player 1, albeit at the potential cost of drawing attention to myself. In case other players follow my lead in voting against Player 1, it might alleviate some of the immediate pressure on the werewolves, but itâ€™s a risky move that could backfire if not supported by a majority or if it appears too aggressive.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports evidence-based decision-making.\nPlayer 2\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Previously claimed seer, confirmed Player 3, and has not been challenged.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by Player 2 and aligned with village interests.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Joined in on caution against unfounded claims but earlier called for meticulous evaluation, possibly mimicking consensus.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: Speaks generally, warns against hasty judgments, but contributes no new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that Player 4\'s stance, while seemingly in agreement with the village\'s emphasis on evidence-based decision-making, has been somewhat nebulous and lacks substantive contributions or concrete information. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Consider the timing and progression of their behavior in comparison to game events.] [8]\n[4] [Reevaluate players who join in on accusations with little to no justification of their own, and scrutinize their subsequent behaviors to determine if they are displaying genuine villager-like concern or are mimicking village consensus to blend in.] [7]\n[5] [Consider the reliability of information from roles like the seer, but also corroborate it with observed behavior and voting patterns to form a more complete picture of player alignments.] [6]\n[6] [Be more critical of players who quickly agree with the majority without providing their own reasoning but vary their approach. This might indicate opportunistic behavior aligned with werewolf tactics.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize consideration for actions that risk a player\'s safety over passive behaviors, as self-sacrificial actions are more typical of villagers than werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [Examine the overall impact of players\' votes throughout the game, looking for patterns that either protect werewolves or target villagers. However, do so in conjunction with other observations and not in isolation.] [5]\n[9] [Closely monitor the justification behind players\' voting patterns, especially when they target another player without clear evidence or seem to vote along with the majority to avoid suspicion. This behavior can be indicative of werewolves blending in with villagers.] [5]\n[10] [Be cautious of players who consistently vote against village consensus without presenting a clear and consistent rationale, as it may indicate werewolf behavior aiming to create discord within the village.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that as a seer, I must act on my instincts and the evidence provided by the behavior of the other players. Player 4 has sowed doubt about my claim as a seer without providing any substantial evidence to the contrary. My strategy emphasizes the importance of communicating werewolf identities when known, and although I do not have definitive proof of Player 4 being a werewolf, my medium confidence level combined with their actionsâ€”which may be interpreted as attempting to discredit the seer to protect themselves or their werewolf alliesâ€”leads me to believe voting for them is the most prudent decision. Aligning with my role, it is critical to take decisive action based on the information available to protect the villagers and to establish trust in my abilities as the seer. The outcome of this vote could either validate my suspicions and strengthen my credibility or cast doubt upon it; however, it is a necessary risk to further the villagers\' cause.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates evidence-based decisions.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports logical reasoning.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Sowed doubt on seer claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted against player 4, likely werewolf ally.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. However, revealing my findings will also increase the risk to myself as the werewolves will likely see me as a major threat and may attempt to eliminate me in the following night phase. It might cause confusion and could undermine my previously stated beliefs, thereby weakening my standing and credibility as the seer. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Increase confidence in a player\'s villager status if their actions consistently align with the village\'s interests and are backed by logical reasoning, even if they do not align perfectly with the majority.] [9]\n[1] [Consider the level and quality of engagement in the game\'s discussions as an indicator of village alignment; avoid focusing solely on silence, as active players can also use engagement as a cover for werewolf tactics.] [9]\n[2] [Reassess players who tend to make generic statements that neither advance the village\'s understanding nor contribute new information, as this could be a tactic to avoid taking a clear stance and might indicate a deceptive role.] [8]\n[3] [Be cautious of early game strong accusations without evidence, but also recognize that players may change tactics as the game progresses. Consider the timing and progression of their behavior in comparison to game events.] [8]\n[4] [Reevaluate players who join in on accusations with little to no justification of their own, and scrutinize their subsequent behaviors to determine if they are displaying genuine villager-like concern or are mimicking village consensus to blend in.] [7]\n[5] [Consider the reliability of information from roles like the seer, but also corroborate it with observed behavior and voting patterns to form a more complete picture of player alignments.] [6]\n[6] [Be more critical of players who quickly agree with the majority without providing their own reasoning but vary their approach. This might indicate opportunistic behavior aligned with werewolf tactics.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize consideration for actions that risk a player\'s safety over passive behaviors, as self-sacrificial actions are more typical of villagers than werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [Examine the overall impact of players\' votes throughout the game, looking for patterns that either protect werewolves or target villagers. However, do so in conjunction with other observations and not in isolation.] [5]\n[9] [Closely monitor the justification behind players\' voting patterns, especially when they target another player without clear evidence or seem to vote along with the majority to avoid suspicion. This behavior can be indicative of werewolves blending in with villagers.] [5]\n[10] [Be cautious of players who consistently vote against village consensus without presenting a clear and consistent rationale, as it may indicate werewolf behavior aiming to create discord within the village.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 6], which indicates that [5, 4, 2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I reassert my position as a villager and advise we all scrutinize behaviors and past events before voting. Consider the facts: Player 5\'s death remains unexplained. As villagers, we should base our decisions on observable evidence, not baseless challenges. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 has advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which I support as our strongest strategy. With Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, we lack clear evidence. Thus, voting should be deliberate and not influenced by unfounded accusations. Player 0\'s call for logical reasoning aligns with the behavior I\'d expect from a fellow villager. My perspective is we prioritize facts over speculation. This method will bring us closer to unveiling the true threats amongst us."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I have confirmed that Player 3 is not a werewolf through my powers as a seer. With Player 5\'s death and no solid leads, we must unite as villagers. Focusing on evidence, as Player 0 and Player 1 suggested, let\'s safeguard confirmed villagers and closely evaluate the unverified Players 4 and 6 for any discrepancies in behavior or statements."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a confirmed villager by Player 2, who is claiming seer status, I place my trust in their insight for now. We have limited evidence, and the guidance of a seer is crucial. I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that Player 2 has claimed the role of a seer without any verification, and their word is the only thing confirming Player 3 as a villager. It\'s important for us to remain critical and questioning, especially when it comes to roles that have significant influence over the game\'s direction. By voting for Player 2, I aim to highlight the necessity of proving one\'s role beyond doubt and to invite others to embrace healthy skepticism. Moreover, casting this vote is part of our strategic effort to protect fellow werewolves and to cast an air of doubt on all players\' roles that have not been confirmed, thus potentially creating an avenue for werewolf survival and control over the game.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistently supports logical analysis and villagers\' strategy.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Received majority votes; werewolves likely avoiding suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Trusted by player 2; may be falsely cleared to gain trust.\nPlayer 5\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact, player is deceased.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Remaining werewolf after player 4\'s elimination.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is due to the emphasis in my original strategy on considering players\' defense and levels of contribution to identifying threats within the village. Player 4 has been more neutral, withheld critical information from the village discourse, and has not contributed new insights. This behavior slightly aligns with rule [2] where repeated defensive actions without justification are deemed suspicious and with rule [4], which speaks to identifying patterns that might detect werewolf manipulation. Additionally, my strategy allows some room for adaptability and refining strategy with new events (rule [8]), thus my vote for Player 4 even without concrete evidence is a calculated risk to draw out more decisive actions and information in the future rounds.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: consistent logical reasoning without suspicion.\nPlayer 2\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: unverified claim, yet remains unchallenged post-voting.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: seer\'s verification invalid after Player 2\'s death.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: cautions against hasty seer claim acceptance but provides no new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Player 2\'s death raises suspicion on their challenges.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Challenge Player 6.\n"I believe it\'s crucial for us to confront the realities we face. Given the information at hand, my advocacy for Player 3 being aligned with the village may lead the actual werewolves to proceed with caution when choosing their next action. \n\nIf Player 6 is indeed a werewolf, as I suspect, they might feel the pressure to either follow up with strong evidence against Player 3 or subtly shift the group\'s attention to another player, possibly even back to me. The werewolves may wish to eliminate me next if they perceive me as a threat who could rally villagers against them.\n\nShould Player 3 be innocent, they may express gratitude or relief at my protection, potentially corroborating their villager status. However, if Player 3 is actually a werewolf, my speech might temporarily lessen the suspicion on them, giving them an advantage in the next voting phase.\n\nWith my honest and protective statement, I am working to maintain a logical, evidence-based approach to the discussion, aligning with the core principles of my strategy. By doing so, I project an image of being rational and consistent, which could solidify my reputation as a trustworthy player among the villagers.\n\nDepending on whether players view my speech as sincere or strategic, they might either side with me, increasing our collective strength, or begin to question my motives, decreasing my influence. Regardless, my position hinges on the continued lack of definitive evidence tying Player 3 directly to werewolf activity.\n\nIn the next day or night phases, if Player 3 survives, it\'s plausible that they may become a focal point of debate once more, especially if additional evidence or counterclaims surface. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 has advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which I support as our strongest strategy. With Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, we lack clear evidence. Thus, voting should be deliberate and not influenced by unfounded accusations. Player 0\'s call for logical reasoning aligns with the behavior I\'d expect from a fellow villager. My perspective is we prioritize facts over speculation. This method will bring us closer to unveiling the true threats amongst us."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I have confirmed that Player 3 is not a werewolf through my powers as a seer. With Player 5\'s death and no solid leads, we must unite as villagers. Focusing on evidence, as Player 0 and Player 1 suggested, let\'s safeguard confirmed villagers and closely evaluate the unverified Players 4 and 6 for any discrepancies in behavior or statements."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a confirmed villager by Player 2, who is claiming seer status, I place my trust in their insight for now. We have limited evidence, and the guidance of a seer is crucial. I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that Player 4\'s stance, while seemingly in agreement with the village\'s emphasis on evidence-based decision-making, has been somewhat nebulous and lacks substantive contributions or concrete information. Following the strategic rules set forth, particularly [1] and [5], evaluating the consistency of Player 4\'s past speeches is vital. Player 4\'s call for a meticulous approach may be a facade to mask their true intentions, and it is essential to enforce the scrutiny that both Player 6 and Player 4 have encouraged. As there has been no solid evidence provided by Player 4 to affirm their role as a villager, and given the focus on logical and evidence-based decision-making in this round, voting for Player 4 aligns with those values and the collective strategy to home in on players whose actions and communications warrant closer examination.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with previous logical reasoning.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Dead and role not revealed.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Survived as supposed werewolf ally died.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Joined in on caution against unfounded claims but earlier called for meticulous evaluation, possibly mimicking consensus.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events related to this player.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voice of moderation may be tactical.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"With the evidence provided, I find the passing of Player 2, who claimed to be our seer, highly suspicious as it followed their validation of Player 3\'s innocence. There has been no challenge to Player 2\'s seer claim, which leads me to trust it by default. Player 6 responded to these events not by contributing new insights but by undermining trust in the seer\'s revelations. Such behavior could indicate werewolf tactics to destabilize our group. Therefore, based on our evolving situation and the absence of counter-evidence, I challenge Player 6 as a possible werewolf."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Increase confidence in a player\'s villager status if their actions consistently align with the village\'s interests and are backed by logical reasoning, even if they do not align perfectly with the majority.] [9]\n[1] [Consider the level and quality of engagement in the game\'s discussions as an indicator of village alignment; avoid focusing solely on silence, as active players can also use engagement as a cover for werewolf tactics.] [9]\n[2] [Reassess players who tend to make generic statements that neither advance the village\'s understanding nor contribute new information, as this could be a tactic to avoid taking a clear stance and might indicate a deceptive role.] [8]\n[3] [Be cautious of early game strong accusations without evidence, but also recognize that players may change tactics as the game progresses. This might indicate opportunistic behavior aligned with werewolf tactics.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize consideration for actions that risk a player\'s safety over passive behaviors, as self-sacrificial actions are more typical of villagers than werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [Examine the overall impact of players\' votes throughout the game, looking for patterns that either protect werewolves or target villagers. However, do so in conjunction with other observations and not in isolation.] [5]\n[9] [Closely monitor the justification behind players\' voting patterns, especially when they target another player without clear evidence or seem to vote along with the majority to avoid suspicion. This behavior can be indicative of werewolves blending in with villagers.] [5]\n[10] [Be cautious of players who consistently vote against village consensus without presenting a clear and consistent rationale, as it may indicate werewolf behavior aiming to create discord within the village.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a seer uncovers a werewolf, regardless of their participation level, I should strongly advocate for the elimination of the identified werewolf and consider the seer\'s insights seriously.] [10]\n[1] [I should evaluate the content and consistency of player\'s past speeches and actions when significant suspicions arise against them.] [10]\n[2] [If a player\'s repeated defensive actions lack clear justification, I should consider this behavior suspicious and call for closer examination of their motivations and alignments.] [8]\n[3] [I should not only focus on eliminated players when evaluating behaviors but also closely monitor how players react to the revealed roles post-elimination.] [8]\n[4] [I should use unexpected game outcomes to identify patterns and refine my strategy to better detect werewolf manipulation.] [6]\n[5] [Even if I previously supported a player, should their defense of others raise valid suspicions, I should be ready to reassess their position and see them as a potential werewolf, keeping in mind the need for strong evidence.] [5]\n[6] [I should be cautious when voting based on other players\' suspicions alone and aim to corroborate with observable evidence or behaviors before making a decision.] [5]\n[7] [If a player predominantly leads to positive outcomes for the village and no strong evidence suggests otherwise, I should consider validating their role; however, I must remain vigilant for any changes in behavior that could indicate deception.] [4]\n[8] [I should be more adaptable during the game, especially after new critical information is revealed, such as a seer\'s investigation result.] [4]\n[9] [When accused without evidence, I should not only defend myself calmly but also try to shift focus toward constructive dialogue that leads to further village insights.] [4]\n[10] [I should seek more context and evidence before voting when a player\'s defense raises suspicion, especially if they could have a critical role for the village.] [4]\n[11] [If new evidence or revelations significantly change the dynamics of player roles and alliances, I should reassess my stance and adjust my vote if necessary.] [4]\n[12] [I should avoid relying solely on the collective perception of suspicion when voting; instead, I should seek additional observable actions or evidence to support the village\'s consensus.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 3, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 6], which indicates that [5, 4, 2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I reassert my position as a villager and advise we all scrutinize behaviors and past events before voting. Consider the facts: Player 5\'s death remains unexplained. As villagers, we should base our decisions on observable evidence, not baseless challenges. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 has advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which I support as our strongest strategy. With Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, we lack clear evidence. Thus, voting should be deliberate and not influenced by unfounded accusations. Player 0\'s call for logical reasoning aligns with the behavior I\'d expect from a fellow villager. My perspective is we prioritize facts over speculation. With Player 5\'s death and no solid leads, we must unite as villagers. Focusing on evidence, as Player 0 and Player 1 suggested, let\'s safeguard confirmed villagers and closely evaluate the unverified Players 4 and 6 for any discrepancies in behavior or statements."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a confirmed villager by Player 2, who is claiming seer status, I place my trust in their insight for now. I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. There has been no challenge to Player 2\'s seer claim, which leads me to trust it by default. Player 6 responded to these events not by contributing new insights but by undermining trust in the seer\'s revelations. Such behavior could indicate werewolf tactics to destabilize our group. Therefore, based on our evolving situation and the absence of counter-evidence, I challenge Player 6 as a possible werewolf."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: No change in belief from last update.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Questioned Player 6\'s behavior, consistent with village\'s interest.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed seer but died early, potential wolf target, aligns with [3] and [5].\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Skeptical of seer without substantiation, possibly sowing doubt.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Behavior aligns with Event analysis, undermines trust without new info.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Challenge Player 6.\nIn this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then Player 6 may become defensive or aggressive in response to being directly challenged, attempting to refute my accusation and possibly counter-challenge either me or another player they suspect to divert attention. If Player 6 fails to provide a convincing defense, it could reinforce my argument and increase the likelihood of other players voting against them. Conversely, if Player 6 presents a strong argument, it could cause uncertainty among the players and potentially cast doubt on my assessment, making me a target for accusations in return. \n\nOther players, specifically Players 0 and 1 who I have high confidence in as villagers, may consider my honest statement and support for the elimination of Player 6 in alignment with our collective efforts to identify werewolves. Given that their current positioning is closer to the village interests, they might support my challenge and may also vote accordingly. \n\nBy taking a stance and openly challenging Player 6, I am making my intentions clear, which shows commitment to my role as a villager. This could lead to a stronger villager alliance emerging that is resolute in strategy and decisions.\n\nIn the next day or night, if Player 6 is indeed a werewolf and is eliminated, it would align with the accuracy of the strategy I followed and further solidify trust in my judgment. If Player 6 is not eliminated, I could either be targeted by the werewolves during the night for trying to eliminate one of their own, or I could be seen as a continued threat by the werewolves and be pressured or challenged during the subsequent day.\n\nIn the days and nights afterward, depending on how the village dynamics change and assuming I survive any possible werewolf attacks or votes against me, I would need to continue aligning with my strategy, assess any new information critically, remain honest in my statements, and make well-reasoned challenges or protections that serve the village\'s best interests. Being consistent would help maintain my credibility within the game.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Protect Player 1.\nFor this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then there\'s a high likelihood that my defense of Player 1 reinforces their perceived credibility as a villager, as my strategic belief in their role is already positive with high confidence. Other players may view my alignment with Player 1 as a sign of trust in the village framework, as both Player 1 and I have shown interest in evidence-based decision-making. My open support may also create a more united front against those we suspect to be werewolves, making it harder for the actual werewolves to manipulate the group without being noticed.\n\nHowever, there is always the risk that Player 6, who is suspected of being a werewolf, will attempt to cast doubt on my reasoning or try to undermine the alliance forming between myself and Player 1. They might argue that we are colluding or that our defense of each other is too convenient. The true werewolves might even target either myself or Player 1 during the next night phase, assuming they see us as threats to their anonymity and success.\n\nIn upcoming days or nights, depending on the reactions and further contributions of Players 0 and 6, the village might be swayed to believe that Player 1 and I are indeed villagers working in the best interest of the village, or we might be viewed with increased suspicion, especially if the werewolves manage to craft a compelling counter-narrative. My honesty in this speech could play to my advantage by fostering trust, or it could backfire if not supported by additional observable evidence that bolsters our claims against the potential werewolves among us.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 6, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 6], which indicates that [5, 4, 2] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [4, 6]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I reassert my position as a villager and advise we all scrutinize behaviors and past events before voting. Consider the facts: Player 5\'s death remains unexplained. As villagers, we should base our decisions on observable evidence, not baseless challenges. An analytical approach will serve us best to root out the werewolves. Hasty accusations could cost us another villager, which the werewolves would see as an opportunity. Let us focus on constructive dialogue and clear reasoning to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 has advocated for evidence-based decision-making, which I support as our strongest strategy. With Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, we lack clear evidence. Thus, voting should be deliberate and not influenced by unfounded accusations. Player 0\'s call for logical reasoning aligns with the behavior I\'d expect from a fellow villager. My perspective is we prioritize facts over speculation. This method will bring us closer to unveiling the true threats amongst us."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I have confirmed that Player 3 is not a werewolf through my powers as a seer. With Player 5\'s death and no solid leads, we must unite as villagers. Focusing on evidence, as Player 0 and Player 1 suggested, let\'s safeguard confirmed villagers and closely evaluate the unverified Players 4 and 6 for any discrepancies in behavior or statements."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"As a confirmed villager by Player 2, who is claiming seer status, I place my trust in their insight for now. We have limited evidence, and the guidance of a seer is crucial. I caution all to remain vigilant and scrutinize further revelations and actions, particularly from players 4 and 6, who remain unverified. Evidence and consistent behavior should guide our decisions, rather than hasty accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"In this time of uncertainty following the loss of Player 5, we must commend Players 0 and 1 for their clear-headed emphasis on evidence and logic. It\'s prudent for us to adopt this approach. Moreover, I see wisdom in Player 3â€™s suggestion to be cautious in our deliberations. Player 2\'s early claim of a Seer\'s vision grants them a powerful voice but without verification, it remains just a claim. Aligning with rational thought, we should consider the possibility of deceit. As a committed member of this village, I encourage a meticulous evaluation of all our statements and actions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Based on the discussions so far, there\'s a common threadâ€”our need to rely on concrete evidence. Player 0 started by advocating for evidence-based decision-making, which Player 1 supported. Player 2\'s claim of being a seer should not be accepted without question. Wisdom comes from scrutiny. Player 4 emphasizes a meticulous approach. Hence, shouldn\'t we also consider the veracity of Player 2\'s claim before accepting Player 3\'s innocence? We must be careful not to hastily isolate suspicions on individuals without solid evidence. This includes not being quick to judge Player 4. Our actions should stem from a collective and balanced examination of the facts presented, without being swayed by unverified claims."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that as a werewolf, it aligns with my strategy to cast doubt on verified villagers and the potentially unverified role of Player 2 as the seer, thereby creating confusion and disrupting the villagers\' strategy. By voting against Player 3, I am adhering to the key components of my strategy, notably to cast suspicion widely and not directly defend my fellow werewolf (Rule 7, Rule 1). This move may cast a shadow of doubt on Player 2\'s credibility as a seer without directly confronting him, fitting into my overall defensive tactics as elaborated in my original strategy. It could stir the pot and direct the focus of the game towards the discussion of Player 2\'s reliability, buying time and creating opportunities for Player 4 and myself.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"With the evidence provided, I find the passing of Player 2, who claimed to be our seer, highly suspicious as it followed their validation of Player 3\'s innocence. There has been no challenge to Player 2\'s seer claim, which leads me to trust it by default. Player 6 responded to these events not by contributing new insights but by undermining trust in the seer\'s revelations. Such behavior could indicate werewolf tactics to destabilize our group. Therefore, based on our evolving situation and the absence of counter-evidence, I challenge Player 6 as a possible werewolf."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Considering the recent death of Player 2, who claimed seer status and backed my role as a villager, and the subsequent suspicions cast upon Player 6, I find it imperative to address this matter clearly. Player 1, who has shown consistent reasoning aligned with village interests, has challenged Player 6 based on the reactions to the seer\'s claims. I stand with Player 1 in this challenge against Player 6, whose behavior raises doubts, notably in their tendency to dismiss the seer\'s insights without providing solid evidence or counter-arguments. Our decisions should remain evidence-based, and the patterns of Player 6\'s response appear more disruptive than constructive. Let us focus our scrutiny and act for the village\'s safety."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Behavior unchanged after major events.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent logic, supports deceased seer\'s claim.\nPlayer 2\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased with their role still unverified, but more likely true given alignment with previous behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Stands with Player 1, consistent with seer\'s validation.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased and confirmed by voting result.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; role remains unclear with no new updates.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is
